sen.j: 付祝言（つけしゅうげん、附祝言とも）は、能における演奏形態のひとつ。
sen.e: Tsukeshugen (付祝言, also written as 附祝言) is one of the performance styles of noh (traditional masked dance-drama).
Tsukeshugen (付祝言, also written as 附祝言) is one of the performance styles of noh (traditional masked dance-drama).

sen.j: 能上演形式による演能が本格的になった江戸時代に登場した。
sen.e: It appeared in the Edo period when en-noh (performing a noh play) in the noh performing style became full-fledged.
sen.cmt: wikipediaでは「能上演形式」が「五番立」になっており、内容からもその方が適切に思われます。そちらを採用される場合、"in the noh performing style"を"in gobandate (five sections of a noh play) style"に差替えて下さい。
sen.e: It appeared in the Edo period when en-noh (performing a noh play) in gobandate (five sections of a noh play) style became full-fledged.

sen.e: It appeared in the Edo period when en-noh (performing a noh play) in gobandate (five sections of a noh play) style became full-fledged.

sen.j: 本来は、五番目の能が鬼畜物など祝言性を持たない曲目であった場合に、一日の演能をめでたく舞いおさめる意味で、さらに一番、祝言の曲を追加して上演したことを指す。
sen.e: Originally it meant performing further an additional celebratory number in order to finish dancing the en-noh of the day happily when the fifth noh was an uncelebratory number such as a play featuring kichiku (brute).

sen.j: 儀式的な演能であるために、多くの場合、前場を省略した半能形式で上演された。
sen.e: Generally it was performed in han-noh style which omitted maeba (the first half of the drama) because it was ritualistic en-noh.

sen.j: そこから転じて、五番立ではない演能会であっても、祝言曲のキリ終曲部分をつけくわえて謡い、本来の付祝言に代える形式が発生した。
sen.e: Having changed from it, there appeared a style that kiri (the concluding segment) of a celebratory number was chanted additionally, taking the place of the original tsukeshugen, even at a noh-performed concert which was not in the gobandate (five sections of a noh play) style.

sen.j: それは最後の曲の後でシテや囃子方が退出した後、地謡だけが舞台に居残って謡われた。
sen.e: The part was chanted by jiutai (noh chorus) that stayed on a stage on its own following the withdrawal of Shite (a main actor of a noh play) and hayashikata (people who play hayashi, or the musical accompaniment) after the last number.

sen.j: 明治維新の後に盛んになったこの形式を、現在ではもっぱら付祝言と称している。
sen.e: This style, which has become popular after the Meiji restoration, is exclusively called tsukeshugen at present.

sen.e: Having changed further from it, there sprang up a custom to add the last part of a suitable number for mourning at a memorial concert and so on.

sen.j: 付祝言に選ばれる曲は、「高砂 (能)」や「難波」のような調子の早い脇能か「猩猩」のような五番目祝言物がふさわしいとされる。
sen.e: Waki noh (a noh whose main character is god) in quick rhythm such as 'Takasago (noh)' and 'Naniwa' or gobanme shugen-mono (the-fifth-section celebratory piece of a noh play) such as 'Shojo' is considered suitable for the number to be chosen as tsukeshugen.
